docs.title: Getting Started
docs.text: Welcome to SpoolBuddy! This guide will walk you through building your own filament management station.

docs.title: Build Process
docs.text:
1. **Order Components** - Review the [Hardware Required](hardware.md) page and order all components. Allow 1-4 weeks for shipping.
  2. **Wire Components** - Follow the [Wiring Guide](wiring.md) to connect all components correctly.
  3. **Assemble Station** - Use the [Assembly Guide](assembly.md) for physical mounting.
  4. **Flash Firmware** - Follow [Firmware Installation](firmware.md) to program the ESP32.
  5. **Setup Backend** - Configure the server using [Software Setup](software.md).
  6. **Start Using** - Connect to your Bambu printer and start managing your filament!

docs.title: Hardware (~$100-150)
docs.text:
Component Purpose Elecrow CrowPanel 7.0" Advance Display + ESP32-S3 Raspberry Pi Zero 2 W Backend server SparkFun Qwiic NAU7802 Scale ADC 5kg Load Cell Weight sensor PN5180 NFC Reader RFID tag reading 22AWG Silicone Wire Connections M4x25 Screws Mounting

docs.text:

  • Don't use J9 header - conflicts with LCD
  • RC522 won't work - need PN5180 for ISO 15693

docs.text:

  • Scale: 5kg capacity, 24-bit ADC
  • NFC: ISO 15693 (Bambu Lab tags)
  • Power: USB-C 5V/2A

docs.title: Assembly Guide
docs.text: Physical assembly and mounting instructions for your SpoolBuddy station.

docs.title: Tools Required
docs.text:
• Phillips screwdriver (small)
  • Soldering iron + solder
  • Wire strippers
  • Double-sided tape or mounting adhesive
  • 3D printer (optional, for enclosure)

docs.title: Mounting Steps
docs.text:
1. Attach to base - Use 2x M4x25 screws on the fixed end. Ensure load cell is level. Tighten firmly.

  2. Attach platform - Use 2x M4x25 screws on the free end. Platform should "float" and only connect via load cell.

  3. Check clearance - Platform should not touch base or sides. Maintain ~2-3mm gap all around.

Critical

The load cell must be the ONLY connection between base and platform for accurate readings.

docs.title: Step 2: Position the NFC Antenna
docs.text:
The PN5180's antenna should be positioned under the scale platform, centered where the spool's core will sit.

            Top View (Scale Platform)
     ┌────────────────────────────────────┐
     │        ┌──────────────┐            │
     │        │    Spool     │            │
     │        │    Core      │            │
     │        │   ╭────╮     │            │
     │        │   │ ○  │◄────┼── RFID tag location
     │        │   ╰────╯     │            │
     │        └──────────────┘            │
     │              │                     │
     │        ┌─────┴─────┐               │
     │        │  Antenna  │◄── PN5180 here
     │        └───────────┘               │
     └────────────────────────────────────┘

docs.title: Mounting the PN5180
docs.text:
1. Position antenna - Center under spool core position, ~10-20mm below platform surface. Antenna coil facing up.

  2. Secure module - Use double-sided tape or 3D printed mount. Keep flat and parallel to platform.

  3. Route wires - Route away from load cell. Avoid wire strain on connections.

docs.title: Read Range
docs.text:
• Bambu Lab tags are inside the spool core
  • PN5180 has ~20cm read range
  • Closer = faster reads
  • Through 3mm wood/plastic: no problem

docs.title: CrowPanel Display
docs.text:
The display can be mounted:

  • Upright - Behind the scale platform
  • Angled - Using a stand for better viewing
  • Integrated - In a 3D printed enclosure

docs.title: NAU7802 Placement
docs.text:
• Mount near load cell terminals
  • Keep I2C wires short (~10-15cm)
  • Protect from vibration

docs.title: Raspberry Pi Zero 2 W
docs.text:
• Mount in enclosure or separate case
  • Ensure good ventilation
  • Keep accessible for SD card

docs.title: Option A: 3D Printed Enclosure
docs.text:
STL files available in the repository under /hardware/enclosure/.

  • Base plate with load cell mount
  • Scale platform
  • Electronics bay
  • Display frame

docs.title: Option B: DIY Enclosure
docs.text:
Materials:

  • Plywood or MDF (6-10mm)
  • Acrylic (for display window)
  • Rubber feet

docs.title: Option C: Bare Assembly
docs.text:
For testing or temporary use:

  • Mount load cell to rigid surface
  • Place PN5180 under test platform
  • Display propped up nearby

docs.title: Mechanical
docs.text:
• Load cell securely mounted at fixed end
  • Platform attached to load cell free end only
  • Platform has clearance (doesn't touch base/sides)
  • NFC antenna centered under spool position
  • Display mounted stably

docs.title: Electrical
docs.text:
• All wiring complete per Wiring Guide
  • No loose connections
  • Wire routing away from moving parts
  • Power cable accessible

docs.title: Verification
docs.text:
• Platform moves freely when pressed
  • No binding or rubbing
  • NFC antenna unobstructed

Next: Firmware Installation

docs.title: Firmware Installation
docs.text: Flash the SpoolBuddy firmware to the CrowPanel Advance 7.0" display.

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
• SpoolBuddy fully assembled (see Assembly Guide)
  • USB-C cable (data capable, not charge-only)
  • Computer with USB port
  • PlatformIO or Arduino IDE installed

docs.title: Option A: PlatformIO (Recommended)
docs.text: PlatformIO provides the best development experience with automatic library management.

docs.title: 1. Install VS Code
docs.text: Download from code.visualstudio.com

docs.title: 2. Install PlatformIO Extension
docs.text:
1. Open VS Code
  2. Go to Extensions (Ctrl+Shift+X)
  3. Search "PlatformIO"
  4. Install "PlatformIO IDE"

docs.title: 3. Clone the Repository
docs.text:
git clone https://github.com/maziggy/spoolbuddy.git
cd spoolbuddy/firmware

docs.title: 4. Open Project
docs.text:
In VS Code: File → Open Folder → select firmware/

PlatformIO will detect the project and install dependencies.

docs.title: 1. Install Arduino IDE 2.x
docs.text: Download from arduino.cc

docs.title: 2. Add ESP32 Board Support
docs.text:
1. File → Preferences
  2. Add to "Additional Board Manager URLs": 
    https://raw.githubusercontent.com/espressif/arduino-esp32/gh-pages/package_esp32_index.json
  3. Tools → Board → Boards Manager
  4. Search "esp32" and install "esp32 by Espressif Systems"

docs.title: 3. Install Required Libraries
docs.text:
Sketch → Include Library → Manage Libraries. Install:

  • lvgl (v8.3.x)
  • TFT_eSPI
  • SparkFun_Qwiic_Scale_NAU7802
  • ArduinoJson
  • WiFiManager

docs.title: Board Configuration
docs.text:
PlatformIOArduino IDE platformio.ini
[env:crowpanel-7]
platform = espressif32
board = esp32-s3-devkitc-1
framework = arduino
board_build.mcu = esp32s3
board_build.f_cpu = 240000000L
board_upload.flash_size = 16MB
board_build.partitions = default_16MB.csv

build_flags =
    -D LV_CONF_INCLUDE_SIMPLE
    -D BOARD_HAS_PSRAM
    -D ARDUINO_USB_CDC_ON_BOOT=1

monitor_speed = 115200
upload_speed = 921600
Setting Value Board ESP32S3 Dev Module Flash Size 16MB PSRAM OPI PSRAM USB Mode Hardware CDC and JTAG Upload Speed 921600

docs.title: DIP Switch Settings
docs.text:
Before connecting, check the DIP switches on the back of the CrowPanel:

Mode S1 S0 Use Normal OFF OFF Running firmware Upload OFF ON Flash new firmware Debug ON OFF Serial debugging

Set S0=ON, S1=OFF for uploading

docs.title: USB Connection
docs.text:
1. Connect USB-C cable to CrowPanel
  2. Connect other end to computer
  3. Display may show blank or old firmware

docs.title: Finding the Port
docs.text:
WindowsLinuxmacOS

Device Manager → Ports (COM & LPT) → Look for "USB Serial" (e.g., COM3)

ls /dev/ttyACM* /dev/ttyUSB*
# Usually /dev/ttyACM0 for ESP32-S3

ls /dev/cu.usb*
# Usually /dev/cu.usbmodem*

docs.title: Flashing the Firmware
docs.text:
PlatformIOArduino IDE
  1. Build: Click the checkmark (✓) or run pio run
  2. Upload: Click the arrow (→) or run pio run -t upload
  3. Monitor: Click the plug icon or run pio device monitor
  1. Select board and port in Tools menu
  2. Click Verify (checkmark) to compile
  3. Click Upload (right arrow)
  4. Open Serial Monitor at 115200 baud

docs.title: Verification Tests
docs.text:
• Display backlight on and LVGL UI renders
  • Touch responds to input
  • Scale shows weight readings
  • NFC detects tags when spool placed
  • WebSocket connects to backend

docs.title: Troubleshooting
docs.text:
Issue Solution Upload fails Check DIP switches (S0=ON, S1=OFF) No port detected Try different USB cable (must be data cable) Timeout errors Hold BOOT button while connecting USB Slow upload Reduce upload_speed to 460800 or 115200 No serial output Enable USB CDC On Boot, check baud rate

docs.title: Hardware Required
docs.text: Complete bill of materials for building a SpoolBuddy station. Total cost: $100-150.

docs.title: 1. Display - Elecrow CrowPanel Advance 7.0"
docs.text:
Specification Value Price ~$50-60 Display 7.0" IPS LCD, 800x480 Touch Capacitive (GT911) MCU ESP32-S3 (built-in) Power USB-C 5V

Purchase:

  • Amazon DE
  • Elecrow Official

Important

Make sure you choose the Advance (AI) version, not the basic HMI version!

Why this display?

  • Built-in ESP32-S3 eliminates separate microcontroller
  • Plenty of GPIO pins for peripherals
  • High-quality IPS touchscreen
  • USB-C power and programming

docs.title: 2. Raspberry Pi Zero 2 W
docs.text:
Specification Value Price ~$15-20 CPU Quad-core ARM Cortex-A53 @ 1GHz RAM 512MB WiFi 2.4GHz 802.11 b/g/n Purpose Backend server

Purchase:

  • Raspberry Pi Official

Alternative

You can also use a Raspberry Pi ¾/5 if you have one available.

docs.title: 3. Scale ADC - SparkFun Qwiic NAU7802
docs.text:
Specification Value Price ~$15-25 ADC 24-bit Interface I2C (Qwiic) Address 0x2A

Purchase:

  • eBay
  • SparkFun Official
  • Mouser

docs.title: 4. Load Cell - 5kg Single Point
docs.text:
Specification Value Price ~$5-10 Capacity 5kg Type Single-point bar Output 4-wire (E+, E-, A+, A-)

Purchase:

  • eBay
  • Search "5kg load cell" on Amazon/AliExpress

Tip

5kg is ideal for filament spools. Higher capacity (10kg) cells have lower resolution per gram.

docs.title: 5. NFC Reader - PN5180
docs.text:
Specification Value Price ~$10-15 Chip NXP PN5180 Interface SPI Protocols ISO 14443A/B, ISO 15693

Purchase:

  • LaskaKit
  • Search "PN5180 NFC" on AliExpress

RC522 Won't Work!

The cheaper RC522 reader does NOT support ISO 15693 and won't work with Bambu Lab tags!

docs.title: 6. Wire - 22AWG Silicone Stranded
docs.text:
Specification Value Price ~$10-15 (kit) Gauge 22 AWG Type Silicone stranded Colors Multiple (for color-coding)

Purchase:

  • Amazon DE

docs.title: 7. Mounting Hardware
docs.text:
Item Quantity Size Purpose DIN 912 Cylinder Screws 4 M4x25 Load cell mounting Nuts 4 M4 Load cell mounting Standoffs 4 M3x10 Display mounting

docs.title: Software Setup
docs.text: Configure the backend server on Raspberry Pi and connect to your Bambu printer.

docs.title: Initial OS Setup
docs.text:
1. Flash Raspberry Pi OS Lite - Use Raspberry Pi Imager, choose "Raspberry Pi OS Lite (64-bit)", configure WiFi and SSH in imager settings

  2. Boot and connect: 

    ssh pi@raspberrypi.local

  3. Update system: 

    sudo apt update && sudo apt upgrade -y

docs.title: Install Dependencies
docs.text:
# Python 3.10+ (usually pre-installed)
python3 --version

# Install pip and venv
sudo apt install -y python3-pip python3-venv git

docs.title: Clone Repository
docs.text:
cd ~
git clone https://github.com/maziggy/spoolbuddy.git
cd spoolbuddy/backend

docs.title: Create Virtual Environment
docs.text:
python3 -m venv venv
source venv/bin/activate

docs.title: Install Python Dependencies
docs.text:
pip install -r requirements.txt

This installs FastAPI, Uvicorn, SQLAlchemy, Paho-MQTT, Pydantic, and Websockets.

docs.title: Environment Variables
docs.text:
Create a .env file:

.env
# Server settings
HOST=0.0.0.0
PORT=3000

# Database
DATABASE_URL=sqlite:///./spoolbuddy.db

# Bambu Cloud (optional)
BAMBU_CLOUD_EMAIL=your@email.com
BAMBU_CLOUD_PASSWORD=yourpassword

docs.title: Manual Start
docs.text:
cd ~/spoolbuddy/backend
source venv/bin/activate
python main.py

Expected output:

INFO:     SpoolBuddy Backend v1.0.0
INFO:     Database initialized
INFO:     Starting server on 0.0.0.0:3000
INFO:     Uvicorn running on http://0.0.0.0:3000

docs.title: Systemd Service (Auto-start)
docs.text:
Create service file:

sudo nano /etc/systemd/system/spoolbuddy.service
/etc/systemd/system/spoolbuddy.service
[Unit]
Description=SpoolBuddy Backend Server
After=network.target

[Service]
Type=simple
User=pi
WorkingDirectory=/home/pi/spoolbuddy/backend
Environment=PATH=/home/pi/spoolbuddy/backend/venv/bin
ExecStart=/home/pi/spoolbuddy/backend/venv/bin/python main.py
Restart=always
RestartSec=10

[Install]
WantedBy=multi-user.target

Enable and start:

sudo systemctl daemon-reload
sudo systemctl enable spoolbuddy
sudo systemctl start spoolbuddy

# Check status
sudo systemctl status spoolbuddy

docs.title: Finding Printer Information
docs.text:
1. Serial Number: Printer Settings → Device → Device Info (format: 01S00A0B0012345)

  2. Access Code: Printer Settings → Network → Access Code (8-digit code)

  3. IP Address: Printer Settings → Network → IP Address

docs.title: Adding Printer via API
docs.text:
curl -X POST http://localhost:3000/api/printers \
  -H "Content-Type: application/json" \
  -d '{
    "name": "My X1C",
    "serial": "01S00A0B0012345",
    "access_code": "12345678",
    "ip_address": "192.168.1.50"
  }'

docs.title: Verify Connection
docs.text: curl http://localhost:3000/api/printers

docs.title: Spools
docs.text: Endpoint Method Description /api/spools GET List all spools /api/spools POST Create spool /api/spools/{id} GET Get spool /api/spools/{id} PUT Update spool /api/spools/{id} DELETE Delete spool

docs.text: Endpoint Method Description /api/printers GET List printers /api/printers POST Add printer /api/printers/{serial}/connect POST Connect /api/printers/{serial}/disconnect POST Disconnect

docs.title: WebSocket
docs.text: Connect to ws://[pi-ip]:3000/ws/ui for real-time updates.

docs.title: You're Done!
docs.text:
Your SpoolBuddy station is now fully set up. Place a spool on the scale and watch it automatically identify the filament!

Troubleshooting

docs.title: Wiring Guide
docs.text: Detailed wiring diagrams and pin connections for all SpoolBuddy components.

docs.title: Safety First
docs.text:
• Always disconnect power before making wiring changes
  • Use 3.3V only for the PN5180 (5V will damage it!)
  • Double-check connections before powering on

docs.title: CrowPanel Connector Layout
docs.text:
┌─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐
│                     CrowPanel Advance 7.0" (Back)                       │
│                                                                         │
│   ┌──────────┐  ┌──────────┐  ┌──────────┐  ┌─────────┐  ┌─────────┐   │
│   │UART0-OUT │  │UART1-OUT │  │ I2C-OUT  │  │   J9    │  │   J11   │   │
│   │  4-pin   │  │  4-pin   │  │  4-pin   │  │  1x7    │  │  1x7    │   │
│   │ SPI CLK  │  │  Scale   │  │          │  │  N/A!   │  │ Control │   │
│   │ SPI MISO │  │  I2C     │  │          │  │CONFLICT │  │  Pins   │   │
│   └──────────┘  └──────────┘  └──────────┘  └─────────┘  └─────────┘   │
│                                                                         │
│   [BOOT]  [RESET]                                           [USB-C]    │
└─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘

J9 Header Conflict

J9 header pins (IO4, IO5, IO6) are used internally by the RGB LCD display! These pins appear shorted to GND when the display is powered on. DO NOT use J9 for SPI - use UART0-OUT header instead.

docs.title: UART0-OUT Header (4-pin)
docs.text:
┌──────┬──────┬──────┬──────┐
│ Pin1 │ Pin2 │ Pin3 │ Pin4 │
│IO44  │IO43  │ 3V3  │ GND  │
│MISO  │ SCK  │ VCC  │ GND  │
└──────┴──────┴──────┴──────┘

BLUE   ───┤ IO44 : ← MISO (SPI data IN)
YELLOW ───┤ IO43 : ← SCK  (SPI clock)
RED    ───┤ 3V3  : ← VCC  (⚠️ 3.3V ONLY!)
BLACK  ───┤ GND  : ← GND

docs.title: J11 Header Control Pins
docs.text:
J11 (Right Side)
        ┌────────┐
Pin 2   │  IO16  │   ← MOSI (SPI data OUT)
Pin 3   │  IO15  │   ← RST
Pin 5   │  IO2   │   ← BUSY
Pin 6   │  IO8   │   ← NSS (CS)
        └────────┘

GREEN  ───┤ IO16 : ← MOSI
BROWN  ───┤ IO15 : ← RST
WHITE  ───┤ IO2  : ← BUSY
ORANGE ───┤ IO8  : ← NSS

docs.title: Complete PN5180 Pin Table
docs.text: PN5180 Pin ESP32-S3 GPIO Header Pin # Wire Color VCC 3.3V UART0-OUT Pin 3 Red GND GND UART0-OUT Pin 4 Black SCK IO43 UART0-OUT Pin 2 Yellow MISO IO44 UART0-OUT Pin 1 Blue MOSI IO16 J11 Pin 2 Green NSS (CS) IO8 J11 Pin 6 Orange BUSY IO2 J11 Pin 5 White RST IO15 J11 Pin 3 Brown

docs.title: UART1-OUT Header (4-pin)
docs.text:
┌──────┬──────┬──────┬──────┐
│ Pin1 │ Pin2 │ Pin3 │ Pin4 │
│IO19  │IO20  │ 3V3  │ GND  │
│ SDA  │ SCL  │ VCC  │ GND  │
└──────┴──────┴──────┴──────┘

YELLOW ───┤ IO19 : ← SDA (I2C data)
WHITE  ───┤ IO20 : ← SCL (I2C clock)
RED    ───┤ 3V3  : ← VCC
BLACK  ───┤ GND  : ← GND
NAU7802 Pin ESP32-S3 GPIO Header Pin # VCC 3.3V UART1-OUT Pin 3 GND GND UART1-OUT Pin 4 SDA IO19 UART1-OUT Pin 1 SCL IO20 UART1-OUT Pin 2

docs.title: Load Cell to NAU7802
docs.text:
Load Cell (5kg)                SparkFun Qwiic Scale
  ┌─────────────────┐            ┌─────────────────┐
  │  Red ───────────┼────────────┤► E+ (Red)       │
  │  Black ─────────┼────────────┤► E- (Black)     │
  │  White ─────────┼────────────┤► A- (White)     │
  │  Green ─────────┼────────────┤► A+ (Green)     │
  └─────────────────┘            └─────────────────┘
Load Cell Wire NAU7802 Terminal Function Red E+ Excitation + Black E- Excitation - White A- Signal - Green A+ Signal +

Wire Colors Vary

Wire colors vary by manufacturer. If readings are negative or erratic, try swapping A+ and A-.

docs.title: Quick Reference Card
docs.text:
┌────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐
│           SPOOLBUDDY QUICK WIRING (CrowPanel 7.0")         │
├────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┤
│                                                            │
│  *** DO NOT USE J9 HEADER - CONFLICTS WITH LCD ***         │
│                                                            │
│  PN5180 (NFC)              NAU7802 (Scale)                 │
│  ───────────               ──────────────                  │
│  VCC  → UART0 Pin3 (3V3)   VCC → UART1 Pin3 (3V3)         │
│  GND  → UART0 Pin4 (GND)   GND → UART1 Pin4 (GND)         │
│  SCK  → UART0 Pin2 (IO43)  SDA → UART1 Pin1 (IO19)        │
│  MISO → UART0 Pin1 (IO44)  SCL → UART1 Pin2 (IO20)        │
│  MOSI → J11 Pin2 (IO16)                                    │
│  CS   → J11 Pin6 (IO8)     Load Cell → Qwiic terminal     │
│  BUSY → J11 Pin5 (IO2)       Red   → E+                   │
│  RST  → J11 Pin3 (IO15)      Black → E-                   │
│                              White → A-                    │
│  Power: USB-C 5V/2A          Green → A+                   │
└────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘

docs.title: Power Requirements
docs.text:
Component Voltage Current (typical) Current (peak) CrowPanel 7.0" 5V (via USB) 300mA 600mA PN5180 3.3V 80mA 150mA NAU7802 3.3V 1mA 2mA Total 5V USB ~400mA ~750mA

Recommendation

Use a quality USB-C cable and 5V/2A power adapter.

docs.title: PN5180
docs.text:
• VCC connected to 3.3V (NOT 5V!)
  • GND connected to GND
  • SCK → UART0-OUT Pin 2 (IO43)
  • MISO → UART0-OUT Pin 1 (IO44)
  • MOSI → J11 Pin 2 (IO16)
  • NSS → J11 Pin 6 (IO8)
  • BUSY → J11 Pin 5 (IO2)
  • RST → J11 Pin 3 (IO15)

docs.title: NAU7802
docs.text:
• VCC connected to 3.3V
  • GND connected to GND
  • SDA → UART1-OUT Pin 1 (IO19)
  • SCL → UART1-OUT Pin 2 (IO20)
  • Load cell wired to E+/E-/A+/A-

docs.title: Troubleshooting
docs.text: Common issues and solutions for SpoolBuddy.

docs.title: PN5180 Not Responding
docs.text:
Symptoms: No tag detection, SPI timeout errors, "PN5180 not found"

Solutions:

  1. Verify wiring - Check all 8 connections against Wiring Guide
  2. Don't use J9! - MISO/MOSI must NOT be connected to J9 (conflicts with LCD)
  3. Check voltage - Measure 3.3V at PN5180 VCC pin (NOT 5V!)
  4. Verify RST pin - Should be HIGH (3.3V) during operation
  5. Reduce SPI speed - Try 500kHz for testing

docs.title: Tags Not Detected
docs.text:
• Tag compatibility: Bambu Lab tags are ISO 15693. RC522 does NOT work!
  • Antenna position: Center under spool core, <20cm from tag
  • Interference: Move away from WiFi router, metal surfaces

docs.title: NAU7802 Erratic Readings
docs.text:
Symptoms: Weight jumps around, negative values, drifting

Solutions:

  1. Check load cell wiring - If readings inverted, swap A+ and A- wires
  2. Stable power - Use quality USB-C cable and 5V/2A power supply
  3. Mechanical issues - Platform must only connect via load cell (no touching sides)
  4. Allow warm-up - NAU7802 needs ~1 minute to stabilize
  5. Shield from drafts - Air currents affect readings

docs.title: Negative Weight
docs.text:
• Swap A+ and A- wires
  • Or configure offset in software
  • Tare after fixing

docs.title: Blank Screen
docs.text:
• Power: Try different USB-C cable (must be data capable)
  • Firmware: Flash with correct board settings, PSRAM enabled
  • Reset: Press RST button

docs.title: Touch Not Working
docs.text:
• GT911 touch controller is internal
  • Check LVGL touch driver initialization
  • May need I2C address configuration

docs.title: Upload Fails
docs.text: Issue Solution No port detected Try different USB-C cable (some are charge-only) Timeout errors Set DIP switches: S0=ON, S1=OFF Permission denied Add user to dialout group (Linux) Wrong board Select ESP32S3 Dev Module

docs.title: No Serial Output
docs.text:
• Build with ARDUINO_USB_CDC_ON_BOOT=1
  • Check baud rate: 115200
  • Press RST button after upload

docs.title: Server Won't Start
docs.text:
# Check logs
journalctl -u spoolbuddy -n 50

# Port in use?
sudo lsof -i :3000

# Missing dependencies?
pip install -r requirements.txt

# Database permissions?
chmod 664 spoolbuddy.db

docs.title: WebSocket Disconnects
docs.text:
• Check Pi resources: htop
  • Check network stability
  • Increase WebSocket ping interval

docs.title: Can't Connect to Printer
docs.text:
Symptoms: "Connection refused", MQTT timeout

Verify:

  1. Network: Pi and printer on same network 

    ping 192.168.1.50  # your printer IP

  2. Credentials: Serial number and access code correct

  3. Printer settings: LAN mode enabled, not in sleep mode

  4. Port: MQTT uses port 8883 

    nc -zv 192.168.1.50 8883

docs.title: Check Hardware
docs.text:
# I2C scan (should show NAU7802 at 0x2A)
i2cdetect -y 1

# Check USB devices
lsusb

# Check serial ports
ls /dev/tty*

docs.title: Check Services
docs.text:
# SpoolBuddy service
sudo systemctl status spoolbuddy

# View logs
journalctl -u spoolbuddy -f

# Restart service
sudo systemctl restart spoolbuddy

docs.title: Check Network
docs.text:
# Pi IP address
ip addr

# Ping printer
ping -c 5 192.168.1.50

# Check ports
netstat -tlnp | grep 3000

docs.title: Check API
docs.text:
# Health check
curl http://localhost:3000/api/health

# List printers
curl http://localhost:3000/api/printers

# Current weight
curl http://localhost:3000/api/scale/weight

docs.title: Getting Help
docs.text:
If you're still stuck:

  1. Check the logs - Usually contains the answer
  2. Search GitHub Issues - Someone may have had the same problem
  3. Join Discord - discord.gg/3XFdHBkF
  4. Open an Issue - Include logs and hardware details
